abstract: The formation of porous anodic alumina during potentiostatic anodizing of aluminium for times up to 900. s has been investigated using two grades of chromic oxide reagent. The anodic films were examined by ion beam analysis and scanning and transmission electron microscopies. Sulphate impurity in the chromic acid led to incorporation of sulphate into the anodic film, a lower current density, a smaller cell size and less feathering of the pore walls. In addition, the efficiency of film formation was increased. The sulphate concentration in the film was greatly enhanced relative to the electrolyte.

author_highlights.sentence: Sulphate impurity in chromic acid significantly affects anodizing of aluminium.
The current density during potentiostatic anodizing is reduced.
Sulphate ions are incorporated into the film.
The efficiency of anodizing and volume expansion factor are increased.
The cell size and feathering of pore walls are reduced.
